title: Data onboarding for enterprise assets
content:
A data onboarding content package for Enterprise Asset Management is available on ITOM Marketplace so that you don't need to build up data from scratch. This instruction will demonstrate how to use the sample files in the content package together with Connect-It to import your enterprise asset data from an external CSV file into the system.

This content package comprises the following files:

  • CSV file to contain all the asset information in a structured format: Sample.csv
  • Log DTD file to keep a record schema of the import process: Sample.dtd
  • Scenario file to define sequential steps or actions during the process: Sample.scn 
  • Description file to provide detailed descriptions of the data's structure and format: Sample.dsc

You will need to use the CSV file and DTD file within Connect-It to generate the SCN file and DSC file as specified. The Connect-It scenario consists of three main elements:

  • The source connector to help to read the CSV files
  • The destination connector to connect to the suite to insert and update the data
  • Data mapping between the source and destination connectors to map the data from the CSV files with the database fields in the suite

Follow the instructions below to finish the data onboarding process for enterprise assets.

Prerequisite

Get CSV file and DTD files of your data prepared to generate the SCN file and DSC file.

Prepare CSV file

Export your enterprise assets data into CSV file. This instruction only involves enterprise assets data, and please refer to the CSV file content below as an example. 

EntityType,DisplayLabel,AssetTag,AssetModel.DisplayLabel,SubType.DisplayLabel,PhaseId,ProcessType,UserOptionsName,UserOptionColor,UserOptionWheels,UserOptionInterior,UserOptionRemote,UserOptionHeated,UserOptionParking,LocatedInStock.DisplayLabel,LocatedAtLocation.DisplayLabel,UOM,Quantity
EnterpriseAsset,530i,1459004,BMW 530i Sedan,Vehicles,pNew,FullOwnership,BMW550iSedanUserOptionType_c,White_c,I19_c,Red_c,y,y,y,,,,
EnterpriseAsset,530i,1459001,BMW 530i Sedan,Vehicles,pInUse,FullOwnership,BMW550iSedanUserOptionType_c,Black_c,I20_c,White_c,n,y,n,,,,
EnterpriseAsset,530i,1459002,BMW 530i Sedan,Vehicles,pInUse,FullOwnership,BMW550iSedanUserOptionType_c,MineralWhite_c,I21_c,Brown_c,y,n,,,,,
EnterpriseAsset,530i,1459003,BMW 530i Sedan,Vehicles,pInUse,FullOwnership,BMW550iSedanUserOptionType_c,Grey_c,I19_c,Black_c,y,n,,,,,

For other related data, such as Asset Model, Enterprise Asset Subtype, Location, and Stockroom, you need to create them manually in the suite.

Note that if Asset Models have user options, Enterprise Assets that share the same Asset Model require a separate CSV file.

Prepare DTD file

DTD file keeps a log record schema of the import process. It will help you easily identify which data record is successfully imported and which one isn't. See the example below as the script of your DTD file.

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!ELEMENT entities (EnterpriseAsset*)>
<!ELEMENT EnterpriseAsset (asset-tag, completion-status?,errorDetails?)>
<!ELEMENT asset-tag (#PCDATA)>
<!ELEMENT completion-status (#PCDATA)>
<!ELEMENT errorDetails (message-rb?,httpStatus?,message-key?,message-arguments?,message?,developer-message?)>
<!ELEMENT message-rb (#PCDATA)>
<!ELEMENT httpStatus (#PCDATA)>
<!ELEMENT message-key (#PCDATA)>
<!ELEMENT message-arguments (#PCDATA)>
<!ELEMENT message (#PCDATA)>
<!ELEMENT developer-message (#PCDATA)>

After this, perform the following steps to import the data during the maintenance period.

Step 1: Install Connect-It

We recommend that you install Connect-It 9.90, which you can download from the Software Licenses and Downloads Portal.

For installation instructions, see the installation chapter in the Connect-It User Guide.

Step 2: Import the CSV files to the suite

This step consists of the following tasks.

Task 1: Configure the source connector

  1. Drag the Delimited text connector from the Toolbox to the Scenario diagram. 
  2. The Name and describe the connector window pops up. Specify a name and description as needed.
  3. Click Next to display the Select a processing mode window, and select Read.
  4. Click Next to display Select a connection protocol window, and select Local/network file(s).
  5. Click Next to display the Select files or folders window, and select Read files. Click  and then browse to the corresponding CSV file.
  6. Click Next repeatedly until you see the Choose a description file window. Click  and then browse to the corresponding description file on your local drive.
  7. Click   to the right of the Use this DSC file field to open the Select a document type window, and then select the description file.
  8. Click Next repeatedly to preview the file. Make sure the Delimiter and Comma options are selected. Click Next.
  9. Make sure that the Import column titles from first line option is selected and the Quote character field is set to the double-quotation mark (").
  10. Click Next until you finish it.

You will have the DSC file when Task 1 is done.

Task 2: Configure the destination connector

  1. Drag the Management as a Service connector from the Toolbox to the Scenario Diagram. The Name and describe the connector window will pop up, specify the name and description as needed.
  2. Click Next to display the Specify the server information window and enter your information.
    Note that the server name should follow the format: <FQDN>:<port>?TENANTID=<tenantId>
    Bulk size should be no more than 5 in case of performance issues.
  3. Click Next to display the SSL Configuration window and enter your information.
  4. Click Next repeatedly until you finish it.
  5. Repeat the above four steps to create another Management as a Service connector. It's called "smax1" in this example.
  6. Right click "smax1" and select Edit a document type.
  7. Under Produced document types, double click the entity EnterpriseAssetSubtype and add the Id, and DisplayLabel fields for it.
     
  8. Repeat step 7 for the following four entities, and make sure you change the Document type field on the top each time:
    Add Id, DisplayLabel fields for AssetModel.
    Add Id, DisplayLabel fields for Location.
    Add Id, DisplayLabel fields for Stockroom.
    Add Id, AssetTag fields for EnterpriseAsset.

Task 3: Configure the mapping

  1. In the Scenario diagram, drag an arrow from the Delimited text connector to the Management as a Service connector to create Mapping.
  2. Right click the Mapping and select Edit a Mapping. Check your source and destination tools and document types, and click OK.
  3. Double click the fields from Destination on the right-side pane as needed, see examples below. They will appear on the middle pane. 
    Operation
EnterpriseAsset.properties.AssetModel
EnterpriseAsset.properties.AssetTag
EnterpriseAsset.properties.DisplayLabel
EnterpriseAsset.properties.Id
EnterpriseAsset.properties.LocatedAtLocation
EnterpriseAsset.properties.LocatedInStock
EnterpriseAsset.properties.PhaseId
EnterpriseAsset.properties.ProcessType
EnterpriseAsset.properties.Quantity
EnterpriseAsset.properties.SubType
EnterpriseAsset.properties.UOM
EnterpriseAsset.properties.UserOptions
  4. For fields such as AssetTag, DisplayLabel, PhaseId, ProcessType, and Quantity, which can be mapped directly, drag the field from the left-side pane to the middle pane to map it.
  5. For Enum fields, use a mapping script to map the field, or leave it as the default value, or skip it.
    For example, the following script maps the out-of-box UOM field: 
    if ['UOM'] = "" Then
    PifIgnoreNodeMapping("No UOM")
End If
RetVal = [UOM]

  6. Initialize Field Mapping/Maptable
    Click Entities > Additional scripts to add scripts.

    ' Add a glbobal variable to set operation to "CREATE" or "UPDATE"
Dim g_sAction as String

Sub OpenSession()
    Dim lErr as Long
  
    ' Create mapping for Location
    lErr = PifCreateDynaMaptableFromFmtName("smax1", "Location","LocationType='StockRoom'", "g_locationMap", "Location.properties.DisplayLabel", 1)
    PifLogInfoMsg("Create Location mapping result: " & lErr)
    
    ' Create mapping for Stockroom
    lErr = PifCreateDynaMaptableFromFmtName("smax1", "Stockroom","", "g_stockroomMap", "Stockroom.properties.DisplayLabel", 1)
    PifLogInfoMsg("Create Stockroom mapping result: " & lErr)
  
    ' Create mapping for AssetModel
    lErr = PifCreateDynaMaptableFromFmtName("smax1", "AssetModel","AssetType='EnterpriseAsset'", "g_assetModelMap", "AssetModel.properties.DisplayLabel", 1)    
    PifLogInfoMsg("Create AssetModel mapping result: " & lErr)

    ' Create Mapping for EnterpriseAssetSubtype
    lErr = PifCreateDynaMaptableFromFmtName("smax1", "EnterpriseAssetSubtype","PhaseId='Active'", "g_subtypeMap", "EnterpriseAssetSubtype.properties.DisplayLabel", 1)
    PifLogInfoMsg("Create EnterpriseAssetSubtype mapping result: " & lErr)
End Sub
  7. If the field is an entity link field, use the mapping script to map the following fields, or leave it as the default value, or skip it. See the scripts below for an example.

    AssetModel

    RetVal=PifMapValue(['AssetModel.DisplayLabel'], "g_assetModelMap", 1, "-1")

    Subtype

    RetVal=PifMapValue(['SubType.DisplayLabel'], "g_subtypeMap", 1, "-1")

    LocatedAtLocation

    Dim value as String

value = PifMapValue(['LocatedAtLocation.DisplayLabel'], "g_locationMap", 1, "-1")
If value = "-1" Then 
  PifIgnoreNodeMapping("No location found for " & ['LocatedAtLocation.DisplayLabel'])
End If

RetVal = value

    LocatedAtStockroom

    Dim value as String

value = PifMapValue(['LocatedInStock.DisplayLabel'], "g_stockroomMap", 1, "-1")
If value = "-1" Then 
    PifIgnoreNodeMapping("No stockroom found for " & ['LocatedInStock.DisplayLabel'])
End If

RetVal = value

  8. Set mapping for operation field
    Use the script below to control if the current entity is created or updated.

    RetVal = g_sAction

  9. Set mapping for Id field
    The script below uses AssetTag as the unique field to query Enterprise Asset. If the query is successful, the ID field is assigned a value and g_sAction is set to UPDATE. Otherwise, the ID field is skipped and g_sAction is set to CREATE (as operation field).

    Dim hQuery as Long
Dim iRc as Long
Dim sId as String

' default to create
g_sAction = "CREATE"  

hQuery = pifNewQueryFromFmtName("smax1", "EnterpriseAsset", "AssetTag='" & ['AssetTag'] & "'")
iRc = PifQueryNext(hQuery)

If iRc = 0 Then
  sId = pifQueryGetStringVal(hQuery, "EnterpriseAsset(0).properties.Id")  
  g_sAction = "UPDATE"
Else 
  PifIgnoreNodeMapping("Skipped, no id field needed for entities to create")
End If

iRc = PifQueryClose(hQuery)

RetVal=sId

  10. Add Global Functions for User Options
    Perform this task to generate a User Options JSON string. For different Asset Models with User Options, follow the steps below as an example to create different JSON strings. From the top menu, Click Scenario > Global functions. Add the scripts below as an example. 

    Function boolJsonValue(ByVal value As String) As String
    Dim returnValue as String
    
    returnValue = "false"
    If value = "true" or value = "t" or value = "1" or value = "y"  or value = "yes" then
        returnValue = "true"
    End If
    
    boolJsonValue = returnValue
End Function

Function stringJsonValue(value) as String
    Dim returnValue as String
    Dim QUOTE as String
    QUOTE = chr(34)

    returnValue = value
    returnValue = Replace(returnValue, QUOTE, "\" & QUOTE)
    returnValue = Replace(returnValue, "\", "\\")

    stringJsonValue = QUOTE & returnValue & QUOTE
End Function

Function jsonName(propName) as String
    Dim QUOTE as String
    QUOTE = chr(34)

    jsonName = QUOTE & propName & QUOTE & ":"
End Function

' --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
' Make UserOption String as following
' {""complexTypeProperties"":[{""properties"":{""Color_c"":""Black_c"",""DynamicComplexTypeRefName_c"":""BMW550iSedanUserOptionType_c"",""Heated_c"":true,""Interior_c"":""White_c"",""Parking_c"":true,""Remote_c"":true,""Wheels_c"":""I20_c""}}]}
' --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Function makeBMWUserOptions(color, wheels, interior, remote, heated, parking) 
    Dim bodyBegin as String
    Dim bodyEnd as String
    Dim body as String

    Dim attrColor as String
    Dim attrWheels as String
    Dim attrInterior as String
    Dim attrRemote as String
    Dim attrHeated as String
    Dim attrParking as String
    
    bodyBegin = "{" & jsonName("complexTypeProperties") & "[{" & jsonName("properties") & "{"
    bodyEnd = "}}]}"
    
    attrColor = jsonName("Color_c") & stringJsonValue(color)
    attrWheels = jsonName("Wheels_c") & stringJsonValue(wheels)
    attrInterior = jsonName("Interior_c") & stringJsonValue(interior)
    attrRemote = jsonName("Remote_c") & boolJsonValue(wheels)
    attrHeated = jsonName("Heated_c") & boolJsonValue(heated) 
    attrParking = jsonName("Parking_c") & boolJsonValue(parking)
    
    body = bodyBegin
    body = body & jsonName("DynamicComplexTypeRefName_c") & stringJsonValue("BMW550iSedanUserOptionType_c") & ","
    body = body & attrColor & ","
    body = body & attrWheels & ","
    body = body & attrInterior & ","
    body = body & attrRemote & ","
    body = body & attrHeated & ","
    body = body & attrParking 
    body = body & bodyEnd
    
    makeBMWUserOptions = body
End Function

  11. Set fields for User Options
    This script sets the User Options JSON value using global functions.

    Dim value as String
value = ""

If ['UserOptionsName'] <> "" Then
    value = makeBMWUserOptions(['UserOptionColor'], ['UserOptionWheels'], ['UserOptionInterior'], ['UserOptionRemote'], ['UserOptionHeated'], ['UserOptionParking'])
Else 
    PifIgnoreNodeMapping("skip user option due")
End If

RetVal = value

Task 4 Configure logs for data onboarding

  1. You can create an XML connector to easily identify which data record is successfully imported and which one isn't. 
  2. Drag the XML connector from the Toolbox to the Scenario Diagram, and configure the connector using the following information as an example:
    Name: xml
    Processing Mode: Write
    Connection Protocol: Local/network file(s)
    Folder Name: C:\work\smax\logs   
    DTD/XSD: Sample.dtd
  3. Drag an arrow from Management as a Service connector to XML connector to create the mapping. See examples below:
    Field Value
    completion-status [EnterpriseAsset.completion_status]
    asset-tag [EnterpriseAsset.properties.AssetTag]
    errorDetails.developer-message [EnterpriseAsset.errorDetails.developer_message]
    errorDetails.httpStatus [EnterpriseAsset.errorDetails.httpStatus]
    errorDetails.message [EnterpriseAsset.errorDetails.message]
    errorDetails.message-arguments [EnterpriseAsset.errorDetails.message_arguments]
    errorDetails.message-key [EnterpriseAsset.errorDetails.message_key]
    errorDetails.message-rb [EnterpriseAsset.errorDetails.message_rb]

You will have the SCN file when Task 4 is done.

Step 3: Run and verify

This step consists of the following tasks.

Task 1 Run the scenario

Right-click the source connector Delimited text, and select Produce now to run the scenario.

Task 2 Verify the imported data

After the data onboarding scenario is executed, follow these steps to verify the data is successfully imported into the suite:

  1. Log in to the suite: https://<hostname>:<port>/dashboard?TENANTID=<tenantId>
  2. From the main menu, select Build > Service Asset & Configuration.
  3. From SACM Home, select Enterprise Assets.
  4. Verify if the data is successfully imported.
